H0.text: Genes control inherited traits in organisms is the statement that best supports Barbara McClintock’s 1931 discovery that genes can change position on a chromosome, as shown by corn plants where moving a gene next to the kernel‑color gene produced kernels of various colors.

H1.text: Corn plants can reproduce in laboratory environments, enabling the observation that moving a gene next to the kernel‑color gene produces kernels of various colors, thereby supporting McClintock’s 1931 discovery that genes can change position on a chromosome.

H2.text: Chromosomes can move around in the nucleus of a cell, supporting McClintock's 1931 discovery that genes can change position on a chromosome and that moving a gene next to the kernel‑color gene in corn plants produced kernels of various colors.

H3.text: Genes are able to disappear and reappear in later generations, supporting McClintock’s 1931 discovery that genes can change position on a chromosome, as demonstrated in corn when moving a certain gene next to the kernel‑color gene produced kernels of various colors.

A4.text: McClintock was able to link specific chromosome groups of traits that were inherited together.

A5.text: McClintock's discovery challenged the concept of the genome as a static set of instructions passed between generations.

A6.text: She found certain parts of the chromosome had switched position when comparing the chromosomes of the current generation of plants with the parent generation.

A7.text: In the winter of 1944–1945, McClintock planted corn kernels that were self‑pollinated.

A8.text: Use of the Sleeping Beauty Transposon System for Stable Gene Expression in Mouse Embryonic Stem Cells

A9.text: A possible connection between aberrant reinsertions and lymphoma.
